contentrichtext.text: '''Jerry Harold Speiser''' (born 1953) is an Australian [[drummer]] and sometime guitarist. He was a founding member of 1980s [[pop music]] group [[Men at Work]];<ref name="WhosWho">{{cite book|title=The Who's Who of Australian Rock|last=Spencer|first=Chris|coauthors=Zbig Nowara, Paul McHenry with notes by [[Ed Nimmervoll]]|url=http://www.whiteroom.com.au/howlspace/whoswho/aboutww.htm|chapter=Killalea, Dominic|chapterurl=http://www.whiteroom.com.au/howlspace/whoswho/PHPMuso.php?categorywho=musos&userasks=33499|origyear=1987|year=2002|publisher=Five Mile Press|location=[[Noble Park, Victoria|Noble Park]], Vic.|page=|isbn=1-86503-891-1|accessdate=9 February 2010}} Note: [on-line] version established at White Room Electronic Publishing Pty Ltd in 2007 and was expanded from the 2002 edition.</ref> which had Australian, United States and United Kingdom hits with their singles, "[[Who Can It Be Now?]]" and "[[Down Under (song)|Down Under]]" and their albums, ''[[Business as Usual (Men at Work album)|Business as Usual]]'' and ''[[Cargo (album)|Cargo]]''. He left the band in 1984 and was a member of other groups including FX, One World and [[Frost (Australian band)|Frost]]. ==Biography== In an early session, he played on Greg Sneddon's ''Mind Stroll'' album in 1974, Sneddon was also part of the initial Men at Work lineup. Following Men at Work's breakup in 1984, he briefly joined pop band FX<ref name="WhosWho"/> (featuring keyboard-player John McCubbery), and then [[Ross Hannaford]]'s band, One World as a guitarist.<ref name="WhosWho"/> In 1986, he and former Men at Work producer and sound engineer Peter McIan had a short stint with American band The City, where he played the drums while McIan played keyboards and produced the album ''Foundation''. After that, Speiser joined pop rockers [[Frost (Australian band)|Frost]]<ref name="WhosWho"/> where he played the drums in the single "You and Me" from their album ''The Usual Suspects''. Speiser (Drums/vocals) and Ben Fitzgerald (Guitars/vocals) co-founded a guitar-driven style rock band named Where's Claire?. In 1990 they were joined by Andrew Midson (Bass/vocals) and Brenden Mason (Guitars/vocals) and released their first commercial album, ''Long Time Coming'' in 2002. He also formed his own low keyed rock band The Working Stiffs and had a single called "Who Can It Be Down Under?" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stereolaffs.com/old_site/rave_on_june.htm |title=Aussie Rock Legend To Settle In Western Maine |publisher=Stereolaffs.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-28}}</ref> Jerry Speiser is now playing as a drummer for an Australian band After Burner. ==References== <references/> ==External links== * [http://www.myspace.com/whereisclaire Where's Claire? on MySpace] * [http://www.crossrocks.com/?p=blockbusters&id=190 Jerry's Cross Rocks' page] * [http://www.myspace.com/downunderthunderdrummer Jerry's MySpace page] * [http://www.stereolaffs.com/old_site/rave_on_june.htm Jerry's Band The Working Stiffs] * http://www.afterburnerband.com/index.html * http://www.elwoodrsl.com.au/afterburner.html {{Men at Work}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Speiser, Jerry | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Australian drummer | DATE OF BIRTH = 1953 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Speiser, Jerry}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Australian drummers]] [[Category:Australian musicians]] {{drummer-stub}}
